title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: said as young hearts—as they had, when rattling CharlieForrest stuck the forget-me-nots in Lily Easton's hat,long, long ago, in the garden at Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: But Mr. M'Nab found out, as many people had donebefore him, that Alatthew's flow of small talk wasalmost interminable, so he expressed sympathy withhim in his troubles, admiring appreciation of hisgardening labours at Greenknowe, and, in bidding himgood-morning, said he would be delighted to get hisplace turned into a paradise by transplants fromGreenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: But Mr. M'Nab found out, as many people had donebefore him, that Alatthew's flow of small talk wasalmost interminable, so he expressed sympathy withhim in his troubles, admiring appreciation of hisgardening labours at Greenknowe, and, in bidding himgood-morning, said he would be delighted to get hisplace turned into a paradise by transplants fromGreenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Are there onyither flowers about Greenknowe that ye wad like totak' wi' ye ? there's plenty to wale frae, an they're a'guid—a' the best; if ye want yer place to be likeParadeese.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Alatthew Eiddell's fortnightly visit to Greenknoweto see " hoo his flowers an' things were doin', an' tosort them," took place on Monday, and Mr. Al'Nabhad to succumb to the old gardener's persistent effortto " show him a'thing."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Al'Nab must stay at Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The evening party at Greenknowe was a merryone; even Jimsie, apparently easier in his go-ashoredress than in his formal blacks, waited with untiringpatience at the piano, turning over the leaves of themusic at uncomfortable arm's-length, and always

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: All landedat Greenknowe, and were sitting at the open drawingroom window, when Air.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: just as Aliss Stewart's hackney carriage was announced,she invited him to join a few young friends whomshe expected, next evening, at Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: He also sent kind regardsto all his Blinkbonny friends, not forgetting the goodsulks at Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Lily Easton called that afternoon at Greenknowe,and, in walking through the garden with Miss Stewart,she saw the gap in the bed of forget-me-not.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: His look was such a compound one, when I delivered it with kind regardsfrom Greenknowe, that despite the efforts of bothto look indifferent, our faces showed that wewere enjoying a capital dumb joke, which soon over-

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: After the visitation was over, Miss Stewart andMr. M'Nab returned to Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: John readily consented to this proposal, and hadarranged to come to Greenknowe on Monday after-

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Mr. M'Nab also spoke of his havingearlier in the afternoon looked in at Greenknowe, andhow the gardener had enlarged about the flowers.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: "TI7HEN Mr. M'Nab went next day to inquire abouthis flower-pot and its valuable contents, hewas accosted, almost immediately on entering theapproach to Greenknowe, by Matthew Eiddell, thejobbing gardener of the village, upon whose broadback lay the responsibilities of the outside work ofmany of the villas of Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The family at Greenknowe formed the subject of along conversation between Mr. M'Nab and my sisterMaggie that night.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Maggie urged Mr. M'Nab to call at Greenknowein the afternoon, partly as a penance, partly as arestorative.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " Why not ? " said Maggie in amazement; then,wishing to recall a more pleasant subject, she added," Go to Greenknowe in the afternoon, Mr. M'Nab;Mary Stewart will charm all fear out of )'ou."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Hastily throwing a shawl over her " morning wrapper,"she carried the soup to the invalids herself, and wason her way home when she caught a glance of Mr.M'Nab coming in the direction of Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: About eleven o'clock in the forenoon he started to ascertain if his pot of " forget-menot" at Greenknowe was thriving.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: He evidently thought so, for on theday following our visit to Greenknowe, the two werein frequent and deep consultation.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: We had not been two hours there beforeJohn manifested a fondness for flowers, that, duringthe five years of our intimacy, I had never observed ;and even for the shrubs that grew in the shadierwalks of Greenknowe, that surprised Mrs. Stewart,whom I companioned, while Mary introduced Mr.M'Nab, judging by the time they took to it, to everyflower and shrub in the garden.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Mrs. Stewartasked us to stay to supper, but, this being the first dayof John's visit to me, we declined her kind invitation,and arranged to spend the Tuesday evening of nextweek at Greenknowe.
